the qustion: Nutrition studies the relationship between food, nutrients, and health.
explanation: True — Definition includes how diet affects growth, healing, and disease prevention. (Slide p. 2)

the qustion: One core function of food is regulation of body processes by vitamins and water.
explanation: True — Food supports energy, building, regulation, and protection. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Macronutrients include carbohydrates, proteins, fats, and water.
explanation: True — Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Carbohydrates and proteins each provide about 4 kcal per gram.
explanation: True — Fats are more energy-dense at ~9 kcal/g. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Trans fats are considered a healthy, preferred fat source.
explanation: False — Trans fats are harmful; choose unsaturated fats. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: A balanced diet draws from all major food groups in appropriate proportions.
explanation: True — Variety ensures adequate nutrient intake. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: The Eat Well Plate divides the plate into ½ vegetables & fruits, ¼ protein, and ¼ grains.
explanation: True — Plus a small dairy portion, hydration, and physical activity. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Serving size on the Nutrition Facts label has no impact on the listed calories.
explanation: False — All values are per serving; packages may contain multiple servings. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: On a % Daily Value scale, 5% DV is considered low and 20% DV high.
explanation: True — Helps quickly assess if a nutrient is low or high. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: "No sugar added" always means the product is sugar-free.
explanation: False — It may still contain naturally occurring or other sugars. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Hydrogenated oils on an ingredient list indicate trans fats.
explanation: True — Watch for hidden fats and sugars. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Aim for lower saturated fat, sodium, and added sugars; higher fiber, vitamins, and minerals.
explanation: True — Core label-reading takeaway. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Low sodium is defined on the slide as ≤140 mg per serving.
explanation: True — Quick threshold to help patients compare products. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Water supports temperature regulation and nutrient transport.
explanation: True — Hydration is part of healthy eating guidance in this deck. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Fiber can support digestion, cholesterol control, and satiety.
explanation: True — Encourage higher-fiber choices on labels and in meals. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Plant proteins cannot contribute meaningfully to protein needs.
explanation: False — Legumes and other plant sources are highlighted as protein foods. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Micronutrients include calcium, iron, zinc, iodine, and vitamins A, D, E, K, B, C.
explanation: True — Minerals (major & trace) and vitamins are micronutrients. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Night blindness is a classic sign of severe vitamin C deficiency.
explanation: False — Night blindness suggests vitamin A deficiency. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Koilonychia (spoon nails) can indicate iron deficiency.
explanation: True — Recognize physical signs of micronutrient deficits. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Poor wound healing may reflect deficiencies in protein, vitamin C, or zinc.
explanation: True — Look for clusters of signs, not just single symptoms. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Edema of the lower limbs can be seen in severe protein deficiency (kwashiorkor).
explanation: True — Protein-energy malnutrition can present with edema. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Pale conjunctiva may indicate folate or iron deficiency.
explanation: True — Common exam finding in anemia. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Easily pluckable, sparse hair can point toward protein-energy malnutrition.
explanation: True — Hair changes are classic signs on the slide. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: DASH diet is defined on the nutrition label slide as eating only low-fat items.
explanation: False — The label tip warns low-fat items may still be high in sugar. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: The ingredient list places items in descending order by weight.
explanation: True — Use it to spot hidden sugars and fats early in the list. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which statement best defines nutrition as introduced in the deck?
a: The study of cooking methods only
b: The science of food, nutrients, and their effects on health
d: A branch of pharmacy focused on supplements
explanation: Correct: The science of food, nutrients, and their effects on health. Nutrition links diet to growth, healing, and disease prevention. (Slide p. 2)

the qustion: Which is NOT one of the listed functions of food?
explanation: Correct: Suppressing immune function. Functions include energy, building, regulation, and protection—not immune suppression. (Slide p. 3)

the qustion: Which grouping correctly identifies macronutrients?
explanation: Correct: Carbohydrates, proteins, fats, water. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which macronutrient provides ~9 kcal per gram?
explanation: Correct: Fats. Carbs and proteins are ~4 kcal/g; fats ~9 kcal/g. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: A balanced diet in this deck is defined as:
a: Eating only one food group to focus intake
b: Providing all nutrients in proper amounts and proportions
explanation: Correct: Providing all nutrients in proper amounts and proportions. Variety across food groups achieves balance. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: According to the Eat Well Plate, how should a plate be divided?
a: ½ protein, ¼ grains, ¼ vegetables
b: ½ vegetables & fruits, ¼ protein, ¼ grains
c: ⅓ each of grains, protein, and fats
d: ½ grains, ¼ fruits, ¼ fats
explanation: Correct: ½ vegetables & fruits, ¼ protein, ¼ grains. Plus hydration and physical activity. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: On Nutrition Facts, all values are based on:
explanation: Correct: One serving. Always check serving size; packages may contain multiple servings. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which % Daily Value interpretation is correct?
a: 5% DV is high, 20% DV is low
b: 5% DV is low, 20% DV is high
d: DV is unrelated to nutrient amount
explanation: Correct: 5% DV is low, 20% DV is high. Use DV to quickly judge low vs high amounts. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which label-reading tip is recommended?
a: Choose items high in saturated fat and sodium
c: Aim for less saturated fat, sodium, and added sugars; more fiber, vitamins, minerals
d: Rely on front-of-pack marketing claims only
explanation: Correct: Aim for less saturated fat, sodium, and added sugars; more fiber, vitamins, minerals. The slide highlights these priorities. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: "No sugar added" on a package means:
a: No sugar of any kind is present
b: It may still contain natural sugars or other sweeteners
explanation: Correct: It may still contain natural sugars or other sweeteners. Read ingredients—hidden sugars can still be present. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which ingredient phrase indicates the presence of trans fats?
explanation: Correct: Hydrogenated oils. Hydrogenation signals trans fats. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: A low-sodium product is defined on the slide as having ≤ how many mg per serving?
explanation: Correct: 140 mg. ≤140 mg per serving is cited. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which is the BEST first step when a bag shows 150 kcal per serving and contains 3 servings?
b: Multiply calories by number of servings eaten
d: Eat the entire bag since it is labeled low fat
explanation: Correct: Multiply calories by number of servings eaten. Total intake depends on how many servings you actually consume. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which combination exemplifies a higher-quality choice per the label-reading slide?
a: High saturated fat, high sodium, low fiber
b: Low saturated fat, lower sodium, higher fiber
explanation: Correct: Low saturated fat, lower sodium, higher fiber. Favor less saturated fat/sodium/added sugars, more fiber. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which is TRUE about macronutrient energy density?
explanation: Correct: Carbohydrate is 4 kcal/g; fat 9 kcal/g. Carb & protein ~4, fat ~9 kcal/g. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which food group list matches the slide?
a: Carbs; proteins; dairy; fruits; vegetables; fats/oils
explanation: Correct: Carbs; proteins; dairy; fruits; vegetables; fats/oils. Six groups are listed, including fats/oils in moderation. (Slide p. 8)

the qustion: Which guidance accompanies the Eat Well Plate slide?
explanation: Correct: Include hydration and physical activity. Lifestyle context is part of the visual guide. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Night blindness most strongly suggests deficiency of:
explanation: Correct: Vitamin A. Classic sign for vitamin A deficiency. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Pale conjunctiva points toward which deficiency?
explanation: Correct: Iron (± folate). Anemia on exam often shows pallor of conjunctiva. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) is associated with:
explanation: Correct: Iron deficiency. Nail changes can indicate iron deficiency. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Poor wound healing can indicate deficits in:
explanation: Correct: Protein, vitamin C, or zinc. Multiple nutrients support tissue repair. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Lower-limb edema can be a sign of:
explanation: Correct: Kwashiorkor (severe protein deficiency). Protein deficiency causes hypoalbuminemia and edema. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Easily pluckable, sparse hair most closely suggests:
explanation: Correct: Protein-energy malnutrition. Hair changes accompany PEM. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which set contains micronutrients as defined in the slides?
explanation: Correct: Calcium, iron, iodine, vitamins. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which is NOT listed as a goal of nutritional status assessment?
d: Eliminate the need for clinical judgment
explanation: Correct: Eliminate the need for clinical judgment. Assessment supports care; it doesn't replace clinical judgment. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which is a GENERAL appearance sign of malnutrition on the slide?
a: Thin, frail body frame with muscle wasting
explanation: Correct: Thin, frail body frame with muscle wasting. Look for visible fat/muscle loss, fatigue/apathy. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Dry, flaky skin can indicate deficiency of:
explanation: Correct: Essential fatty acids or zinc. Skin changes reflect specific nutrient deficits. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Hyperpigmented rash (pellagra) is most associated with low:
explanation: Correct: Niacin. Pellagra = niacin deficiency. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Numbness or tingling in hands/feet may suggest low:
explanation: Correct: B12 or B6. Neuropathy signs appear with certain B-vitamin deficits. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Poor coordination on the slide is linked to which deficiency?
explanation: Correct: Thiamine (B1). Neurologic signs are highlighted for B1. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Confusion or memory issues can reflect deficiency of:
explanation: Correct: Thiamine or B12. Several micronutrients affect cognition. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Which is the most practical label step to teach patients first?
a: Check the ingredient list for order by weight
explanation: Correct: Check the ingredient list for order by weight. Ingredients are listed by weight; spot hidden sugars/fats early. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which advice aligns with reducing added sugars per the slides?
a: Choose products with corn syrup or dextrose high in the list
b: Prefer 'no sugar added' and still check ingredients
c: Assume fruit juice is always low in sugar
d: Ignore added sugars if fiber is high
explanation: Correct: Prefer 'no sugar added' and still check ingredients. Names like corn syrup/fructose/dextrose signal sugars. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which label combo best reflects a healthier cereal choice?
a: High added sugar, low fiber, high sodium
b: Low added sugar, higher fiber, moderate sodium
explanation: Correct: Low added sugar, higher fiber, moderate sodium. Balance fiber up, added sugars and sodium down. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which statement about 'low fat' products is highlighted?
a: They are always low in calories
b: They may still be high in sugar
explanation: Correct: They may still be high in sugar. Watch for compensatory added sugars. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which pair is correctly matched with its primary role?
d: Fats — no role in vitamin absorption
explanation: Correct: Proteins — tissue repair. Protein repairs/builds; fats help absorb fat-soluble vitamins. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which set is encouraged for plate building?
a: Half the plate vegetables/fruits, quarter protein, quarter grains
b: Half the plate fats, quarter protein, quarter grains
c: Half the plate grains, quarter fats, quarter protein
d: Equal parts fats, sweets, and grains
explanation: Correct: Half the plate vegetables/fruits, quarter protein, quarter grains. Visual division supports balance. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which option best describes fiber's benefits from the label slide?
explanation: Correct: Supports digestion, cholesterol control, satiety. Fiber is highlighted as a positive nutrient to increase. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which strategies help patients use labels wisely?
c: Scan ingredient list for hidden sugars/fats
explanation: Correct: All of the above. The slide teaches all three together. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which foods fit 'healthy fats' guidance from the deck?
explanation: Correct: Nuts, seeds, olive oil (unsaturated). Choose unsaturated fats; avoid trans fats. (Slide p. 5)

the qustion: Which statement about hydration is consistent with the deck?
c: Hydration is unrelated to healthy eating
d: Thirst is the only guide needed for everyone
explanation: Correct: Water supports thermoregulation and transport. Hydration and activity are included with the plate guidance. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which ingredient list is MOST concerning for hidden sugars?
a: Whole grain, almonds, cinnamon, sea salt
explanation: Correct: Corn syrup, fructose, dextrose, molasses. These names are common forms of added sugars. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which choice reflects a smart sodium strategy per the slides?
a: Choose ≤140 mg per serving when possible
c: Assume all soups are low sodium
explanation: Correct: Choose ≤140 mg per serving when possible. ≤140 mg/serving is the cited 'low sodium' cut-off. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which pairing is CORRECT regarding nutrient type?
explanation: Correct: Vitamin C — micronutrient. Vitamins and minerals are micronutrients; protein and water are not. (Slide p. 4)

the qustion: Which food label element is MOST likely to mislead if read alone?
explanation: Correct: Front-of-pack claims like 'natural' or 'organic'. The slide warns about 'health halos'; the label details matter. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which snack aligns BEST with the plate & label guidance?
b: Apple slices with peanut butter; water
explanation: Correct: Apple slices with peanut butter; water. Combine whole foods, fiber, and hydration. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which statement about ingredient lists is TRUE?
b: Ingredients are listed by descending weight
c: Ingredients are listed by vitamin content
explanation: Correct: Ingredients are listed by descending weight. This helps identify predominant ingredients. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which is the BEST quick check for a bread label?
a: High added sugars and low fiber
b: Whole grain listed early; higher fiber; moderate sodium
d: Choose based on color of bread only
explanation: Correct: Whole grain listed early; higher fiber; moderate sodium. Apply serving size, fiber up, sugars/sodium down. (Slide p. 11)

the qustion: Which meal best matches the plate guidance?
a: Grilled chicken, brown rice, large mixed salad; water
c: White pasta with cream sauce; juice
explanation: Correct: Grilled chicken, brown rice, large mixed salad; water. Half veg/fruit, quarters grains/protein, plus hydration. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which of the following is a macro-to-micro CORRECT match?
explanation: Correct: Fats — macronutrient; Iron — micronutrient. Macro = carbs/protein/fats/water; micro = vitamins/minerals. (Slide p. 4)
